thread.title: Loch Ness hunter concludes monster is just a large catfish [Photos] [Video]
thread.title_full: Loch Ness hunter concludes monster is just a large catfish [Photos] [Video]

title: Loch Ness hunter concludes monster is just a large catfish [Photos] [Video]
text:
Top spots to see mythical creatures 
A man who has camped by the banks of Scotland's Loch Ness for 24 years in hopes of finally discovering the legendary Loch Ness Monster has given up his hunt, concluding that any activity in the loch is just from a very large catfish. 
Steve Feltham, 52, gave up his home and job in England in 1991 to move to the shores of Scotland's second largest loch and search for the elusive water monster. Speaking to Sky News on Thursday , Feltham admitted he was unable to solve the mystery. 
"Looking at all the evidence, speaking to eyewitnesses, the most likely solution is a Wels catfish," Feltham said. The breed of catfish is native to Europe and can grow up to four metres in length. 
Feltham told Sky News he had no regrets about spending nearly 25 years hunting for the Loch Ness Monster, saying "I'm in my utopia living here on the shores of the loch." 
There have been countless Loch Ness Monster "sightings" over the years. The most famous is the so-called black-and-white surgeon's photo captured in 1934. The photo was later revealed to be a hoax. 
The BBC reports about 1 million people visit Loch Ness each year. Top spots to see mythical creatures Previous Next 
Ogopogo, the lake monster living in British Columbia's Lake Okanagan, has been spotted by many and even captured on video tape. Native tribes in the Okanagan would carry animals with them on hunting expeditions to sacrifice, should they see the Ogopogo. (QMI Agency File) 
This is a 1934 photo of what some people believe to be the Loch Ness Monster. It was later proved to be a hoax photo, but the Loch Ness Monster, at Loch Ness in Scotland, is perhaps one of the greatest mythological creatures of our time. Hunters continue to search the Loch in hopes of finding concrete evidence of Nessie. 
If you'd like to spot a Chupacabra, or Goat Sucker, head to Central and South America. Sightings have been reported from as far south as Chile to Maine. The creature is said to be the size of a bear, with reptilian skin and spines running down its back. (Wikipedia) 
A tall, fur covered being with the torso and arms of a man and legs of a goat, the Goatman was seen roaming Maryland, U.S.A. Witnesses say they've heard high pitched squeals coming from the Goatman and it should be considered dangerous, as its apparently attacked people and property. (Shutterstock) 
The Cadborosaurus has been spotted in the waters of British Columbia and Pacific Northwest. The creature was initially discovered when fisherman found an odd skeleton in the belly of a whale. It had a head like a donkey, fins and a serpentine body. Another captain describes catching a small version of the animal in a bucket while sailing, but released it into the sea. (British Columbia Archives and Record Service) 
The Yeti, or Abominable Snowman, is a legendary creature believed to roam the Himalayas of Nepal and Tibet. Explorers have told tales of strange footprints and creatures with long hair who fled in fear. Many believe the Yeti is another animal misidentified. (Dave Chidley/QMI Agency) 
Almas, "wild" human-like creatures in the Caucasus and Pamir mountains of Central Asia and Altai mountains of southern Mongolia, are covered in reddish brown fur and have weak features, resembling Neanderthals. (Shutterstock) 
Another famous "cryptid" creature is the Big Foot, or Sasquatch. There have been several sightings, as well as blurry video footage. It can be found in the remote British Columbia forests and Northern Pacific coast of US & Canada. (Shutterstock) 
Kraken is a monstrous squid type creature spotted off the coasts of Norway and Iceland. One wouldn't want this sea monster attacking their ship. While there have been very large squid pulled from the sea in recent years, this is likely an old fisherman's tale. (Wikipedia) 
Jackalopes have reportedly been seen scurrying around Wyoming, U.S.A., The creature is part rabbit and part antelope. Many say this has been confused with "hope papillomavirus," a disease which causes horn and antler like tumours on a rabbit's head and body. (Wikipedia) Reader's comments Â»
